column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.RoleAnnotation|roles
#Text=Mr.
#Text=Mwakawago (United Republic of Tanzania):\r
#Text=It gives my delegation particular pleasure to see you,\r
#Text=Sir, presiding over this open debate on women and\r
#Text=peace and security.
#Text=My delegation warmly welcomes\r
#Text=the convening of this meeting and hopes that the\r
#Text=outcome of this historic debate will contribute to a\r
#Text=better understanding of the gender dimension of peace\r
#Text=processes.
#Text=It is significant that in recognition of the\r
#Text=importance that your country attaches to this issue, the\r
#Text=seminar on "Mainstreaming a Gender Perspective in\r
#Text=Multidimensional Peace Support Operations" was held\r
#Text=in Windhoek from 29 to 31 May 2000.
#Text=In this regard\r
#Text=my delegation supports the Namibia Plan of Action and\r
#Text=the call made to the Secretary-General to ensure that\r
#Text=appropriate follow-up measures are undertaken to\r
#Text=implement it.
#Text=This debate on women, peace and security is an\r
#Text=important reminder to all of us of the need to resolve\r
#Text=conflicts, particularly those in Africa and elsewhere\r
#Text=which are of grave concern to all of us.
#Text=Due to these\r
#Text=conflicts, about six million Africans are refugees and\r
#Text=over 15 million people are displaced, between 60 and\r
#Text=80 per cent of whom are women and children.
#Text=The 2000 Machel review points out, in chapter 5,\r
#Text=that:\r
#Text=\r
#Text="During armed conflict, women and girls are\r
#Text=continually threatened by rape, domestic\r
#Text=violence, sexual exploitation, trafficking, sexual\r
#Text=humiliation and mutilation."
#Text=They are at risk in all settings - be it at home, in flight\r
#Text=or in camps.
#Text=In some cases, systematic rape and terror\r
#Text=are used as weapons of war.
#Text=After having been\r
#Text=subjected to such atrocities, they are left with scars that\r
#Text=take longer to heal.
#Text=There is no denying that it is women who\r
#Text=shoulder the responsibility of supporting their families\r
#Text=and communities.
#Text=Women serve alongside their male\r
#Text=counterparts in times of war.
#Text=It is also women who\r
#Text=serve at the forefront of peace movements.
#Text=Under these\r
#Text=circumstances, it is evident that we cannot continue\r
#Text=excluding women from conflict resolution processes.
#Text=Expanding the role of women in this area is imperative,\r
#Text=not only to address inequities but also to ensure that\r
#Text=our societies benefit from their approaches to\r
#Text=preventing conflicts, solving conflicts and building\r
#Text=peace.
#Text=Being direct victims of violence and\r
#Text=discrimination, women have gained a great\r
#Text=understanding of the need to address peace\r
#Text=comprehensively.
#Text=It is encouraging to note that given\r
#Text=the prevalence of conflicts, particularly in Africa today,\r
#Text=women have taken some initiatives to promote peaceful\r
#Text=resolution of conflicts and to generate a culture of\r
#Text=peace.
#Text=In this context, the role of Burundian women in\r
#Text=the peace process in their country - and the\r
#Text=recognition of that role by President Nelson Mandela,\r
#Text=the Facilitator of the Burundi peace process - should\r
#Text=serve as an example and as a source of inspiration to\r
#Text=the international community.
#Text=It is the hope of my\r
#Text=delegation that the Council will adopt a resolution that\r
#Text=gives due weight to the role that women can play in\r
#Text=peace negotiations and accord them due recognition.
#Text=The international community needs, therefore, to agree\r
#Text=on a framework that guarantees women that right.
#Text=Both the final outcome document of the twenty-\r
#Text=third special session of the General Assembly entitled\r
#Text="Women 2000: gender equality, development and peace\r
#Text=for the twenty-first century" and the Millennium\r
#Text=Summit Declaration place emphasis on shared\r
#Text=responsibility to maintain international peace and\r
#Text=security.
#Text=On the occasion of International Women's\r
#Text=Day on 8 March, the then President of the Security\r
#Text=Council, Ambassador Chowdhury of Bangladesh,\r
#Text=observed in a statement to the Press:\r
#Text=\r
#Text="Members of the Council note that although\r
#Text=women have begun to play an important role in\r
#Text=conflict resolution, peacekeeping and peace-\r
#Text=building, they are still under-represented in\r
#Text=decision-making in regard to conflict.

#Text=If women\r
#Text=are to play an equal part in security and\r
#Text=maintaining peace, they must be empowered\r
#Text=politically and economically, and represented\r
#Text=adequately at all levels of decision-making, both\r
#Text=at the pre-conflict stage and during hostilities, as\r
#Text=well as at the point of peacekeeping, peace-\r
#Text=building, reconciliation and reconstruction.

_	

#Text=In reiterating this position, we call on the international\r
#Text=community and Governments to intensify efforts aimed\r
#Text=at the realization of the objective set out in that\r
#Text=statement, including the enhancement of the role of\r
#Text=women in various phases of the transition to peace and\r
#Text=post-conflict reconstruction.
